soln_description:
## Solution.

## Rewrite the equation as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin ^{2} z+\cos ^{2} z+\sin z+\cos z+2 \sin z \cos z+\cos ^{2} z-\sin ^{2} z=0 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow(\sin z+\cos z)+\left(2 \sin z \cos z+2 \cos ^{2} z\right)=0 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow(\sin z+\cos z)+2 \cos z(\sin z+\cos z)=0 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow(\sin z+\cos z)(1+2 \cos z)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

From this, 1) $\sin z+\cos z=0$, 2) $1+2 \cos z=0$.

1) $\operatorname{tg} z=-1, z_{1}=-\frac{\pi}{4}+\pi k=\frac{\pi}{4}(4 k-1), k \in Z$.
2) $\cos z=-\frac{1}{2}, z_{2}= \pm \frac{2}{3} \pi+2 \pi n=\frac{2}{3} \pi(3 n \pm 1), n \in Z$.

Answer: $z_{1}=\frac{\pi}{4}(4 k-1) ; z_{2}=\frac{2}{3} \pi(3 n \pm 1)$, where $k$ and $n \in Z$.
informal_statement: 8.340. $1+\sin z+\cos z+\sin 2z+\cos 2z=0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- 8.340. $1+\sin z+\cos z+\sin 2z+\cos 2z=0$. -/
theorem algebra_169655 {z : ℝ} (hz : 1 + sin z + cos z + sin (2 * z) + cos (2 * z) = 0) :
    ∃ k n : ℤ, z = (π / 4) * (4 * k - 1) ∨ z = (2 * π / 3) * (3 * n + 1) := by

soln_description:
Proof. If $r=1$ or $s=1$, then the lemma is obviously true, so we may suppose that $r>1$ and $s>1$. Let the prime-power factorizations of $r, s$, and $t$ be
$$\begin{array}{l}
r=p_{1}^{a_{1}} p_{2}^{a_{2}} \cdots p_{u}^{a_{*}} \\
s=p_{u+1}^{a_{u+1}} p_{u+2}^{a_{*+2}} \cdots \cdots p_{v}^{a_{v}^{v}}
\end{array}$$
and
$$t=q_{1}^{b_{1}} q_{2}^{b_{2}} \cdots q_{k}^{b_{k}}$$

Since $(r, s)=1$, the primes occurring in the factorizations of $r$ and $s$ are distinct. Since $r s=t^{2}$, we have
$$p_{1}^{a_{1}} p_{2}^{a_{2}} \cdots p_{u}^{a_{*}} p_{u+1}^{a_{*+1}} p_{u+2}^{a_{*+2}} \cdots p_{v}^{a_{v}}=q_{1}^{2 b_{1}} q_{2}^{2 b_{2}} \cdots q_{k}^{2 b_{k}}$$

From the fundamental theorem of arithmetic, the prime-powers occurring on the two sides of the above equation are the same. Hence, each $p_{i}$ must be equal to $q_{j}$ for some $j$ with matching exponents, so that $a_{i}=2 b_{j}$. Consequently, every exponent $a_{i}$ is even, and therefore $a_{i} / 2$ is an integer. We see that $r=m^{2}$ and $s=n^{2}$, where $m$ and $n$ are the integers
$$m=p_{1}^{a_{1} / 2} p_{2}^{a_{2} / 2} \cdots p_{u}^{a_{u} / 2}$$
and
$$n=p_{u^{u+1}}^{a_{+1} / 2} p_{u+2}^{a_{u+1} / 2} \cdots p_{v}^{a_{v} / 2}$$
informal_statement: Lemma 11.3. If $r, s$, and $t$ are positive integers such that $(r, s)=1$ and $r s=t^{2}$, then there are integers $m$ and $n$ such that $r=m^{2}$ and $s=n^{2}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Lemma 11.3. If $r, s$, and $t$ are positive integers such that $(r, s)=1$ and $r s=t^{2}$, then there are integers $m$ and $n$ such that $r=m^{2}$ and $s=n^{2}$ -/
theorem number_theory_5314
    (r s t : ℕ)
    (h₀ : 0 < r)
    (h₁ : 0 < s)
    (h₂ : 0 < t)
    (h₃ : Nat.gcd r s = 1)
    (h₄ : r * s = t^2) :
    ∃ m n, r = m^2 ∧ s = n^2 := by

soln_description:
Prove the two lemmas first.

Lemma 1 If positive integers $m, n, k$ satisfy
$$
m n=k^{2}+1,
$$

then there exist $x_{1}, x_{2}, y_{1}, y_{2} \in \mathbf{N}$, such that the following three equations
$$
m=x_{1}^{2}+y_{1}^{2}, n=x_{2}^{2}+y_{2}^{2}, k=x_{1} x_{2}+y_{1} y_{2}
$$

hold simultaneously.
Proof of Lemma 1 Without loss of generality, assume $m \leqslant n$, and use induction on $k$.

When $k=1$, since $m n=2$, then $m=1, n=2$, at this time,
$$
m=0^{2}+1^{2}, n=1^{2}+1^{2}, k=0 \times 1+1 \times 1,
$$

i.e., the conclusion holds for $k<2$.
Assume the conclusion holds for $k<r (r \geqslant 2)$.
When $k=r$, from
$$
m n=r^{2}+1,
$$

then $n \geqslant r+1$,
i.e., the conclusion holds for $k=r$.
By mathematical induction, Lemma 1 is proved.
Lemma 2 For any $m, n \in \mathbf{N}$, we have
$$
a_{m+n}+b_{m+n}=a_{m} a_{n}+b_{m} b_{n}
$$

Proof of Lemma 2 It suffices to prove that for $0 \leqslant k \leqslant m+n$, we have
$$
a_{m+n}+b_{m+n}=a_{k} a_{m+n-k}+b_{k} b_{m+n-k}.
$$

Use induction on $k$.
When $k=0$, the conclusion is obvious.
When $k=1$, since
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{m+n}=\alpha a_{m+n-1}+\beta a_{m+n-1}, \\
b_{m+n}=\beta a_{m+n-1}+\gamma b_{m+n-1},
\end{array}
$$

then $a_{m+n}+b_{m+n}$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=(\alpha+\beta) a_{m+n-1}+(\beta+\gamma) b_{m+n-1} \\
=a_{1} a_{m+n-1}+b_{1} b_{m+n-1}.
\end{array}
$$

Assume when $k=p$, we have
$$
a_{m+n}+b_{m+n}=a_{p} a_{m+n-p}+b_{p} b_{m+n-p}.
$$

Then when $k=p+1$,
$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{m+n}+b_{m+n}=a_{p} a_{m+n-p}+b_{p} b_{m+n-p} \\
= & a_{p}\left(\alpha a_{m+n-p-1}+\beta b_{m+n-p-1}\right)+ \\
& b_{p}\left(\beta a_{m+n-p-1}+\gamma b_{m+n-p-1}\right) \\
= & \left(\alpha a_{p}+\beta b_{p}\right) a_{m+n-p-1}+ \\
& \left(\beta a_{p}+\gamma b_{p}\right) b_{m+n-p-1} \\
= & a_{p+1} a_{m+n-p-1}+b_{p+1} b_{m+n-p-1}.
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, equation (3) holds.
In equation (3), let $k=m$, then
$a_{m+n}+b_{m+n}=a_{m} a_{n}+b_{m} b_{n}$.
Lemma 2 is proved.
Return to the original problem.
According to Lemma 2, in equation (2), let $m=n$, then $a_{2 n}+b_{2 n}=a_{n}^{2}+b_{n}^{2}$.
Also, take $m=n+1$, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{2 n+1}+b_{2 n+1}=a_{n+1} a_{n}+b_{n+1} b_{n} \\
=\left(\alpha a_{n}+\beta b_{n}\right) a_{n}+\left(\beta a_{n}+\gamma b_{n}\right) b_{n} \\
=\alpha a_{n}^{2}+\gamma b_{n}^{2}+2 \beta a_{n} b_{n} \\
=\left(x_{1}^{2}+y_{1}^{2}\right) a_{n}^{2}+\left(x_{2}^{2}+y_{2}^{2}\right) b_{n}^{2}+ \\
2\left(x_{1} x_{2}+y_{1} y_{2}\right) a_{n} b_{n} \\
=\left(x_{1} a_{n}+x_{2} b_{n}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{1} a_{n}+y_{2} b_{n}\right)^{2}.
\end{array}
$$

Then in equation (1), we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
m=x_{1}^{2}+y_{1}^{2}, n=x_{2}^{2}+y_{2}^{2}, k=x_{1} x_{2}+y_{1} y_{2}, \\
x_{1}, x_{2}, y_{1}, y_{2} \in \mathbf{N},
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the conclusion is proved.
informal_statement:
Example 2 Let the sequences $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ satisfy
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{0}=b_{0}=1, \\
a_{n+1}=\alpha a_{n}+\beta b_{n}, b_{n+1}=\beta a_{n}+\gamma b_{n},
\end{array}
$$

where $\alpha, \gamma$ are positive integers, $\alpha<\gamma$, and $\alpha \gamma=\beta^{2}+1$. Prove that for any $n \in \mathbf{N}, a_{n}+b_{n}$ can always be expressed as the sum of the squares of two positive integers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 2 Let the sequences $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ satisfy
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{0}=b_{0}=1, \\
a_{n+1}=\alpha a_{n}+\beta b_{n}, b_{n+1}=\beta a_{n}+\gamma b_{n},
\end{array}
$$

where $\alpha, \gamma$ are positive integers, $\alpha<\gamma$, and $\alpha \gamma=\beta^{2}+1$. Prove that for any $n \in \mathbf{N}, a_{n}+b_{n}$ can always be expressed as the sum of the squares of two positive integers. -/
theorem algebra_320314 (a b : ℕ → ℤ) (α β γ : ℕ)
    (h₀ : a 0 = 1) (h₁ : b 0 = 1)
    (h₂ : α > 0) (h₃ : β > 0) (h₄ : γ > 0)
    (h₅ : α < γ) (h₆ : α * γ = β ^ 2 + 1)
    (h₇ : ∀ n, a (n + 1) = α * a n + β * b n)
    (h₈ : ∀ n, b (n + 1) = β * a n + γ * b n) :
    ∀ n, ∃ m p, a n + b n = m ^ 2 + p ^ 2 ∧ m > 0 ∧ p > 0 := by

informal_statement: ___Amy___ reads a novel, reading $1$ page on the first day, $2$ pages on the second day, $3$ pages on the third day, and so on, until the total number of pages read is a multiple of $80$. How many pages did ___Amy___ read in total?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ___Amy___ reads a novel, reading $1$ page on the first day, $2$ pages on the second day, $3$ pages on the third day, and so on, until the total number of pages read is a multiple of $80$. How many pages did ___Amy___ read in total? -/
theorem number_theory_6703 (n : ℕ) (h : n > 0) :
    IsLeast {x | ∃ k, x = ∑ i ∈ Finset.range k, (i + 1) ∧ 80 ∣ x} n := by

soln_description:
II. 1. From the given, $\left(a-3 a^{\prime}\right) x^{2}+\left(b-3 b^{\prime}\right) x+(c$ $\left.-3 c^{\prime}\right)=0$ is an identity, hence $\left(a-3 a^{\prime}\right)=0,\left(b-3 b^{\prime}\right)=0$, $\left(c-3 c^{\prime}\right)=0$, which gives $\frac{a}{a^{\prime}}=\frac{b}{b^{\prime}}=\frac{c}{c^{\prime}}=3$,
$\therefore \triangle A B C \sim \triangle A^{\prime} B^{\prime} C^{\prime}$, then $\frac{S}{S^{\prime}}=\left(\frac{a}{a^{\prime}}\right)^{2}=9$.
informal_statement: 1. Let $\triangle A B C$ and $\triangle A^{\prime} B^{\prime} C^{\prime}$ have side lengths $a, b, c$ and $a^{\prime}, b^{\prime}, c^{\prime}$, respectively, and their areas be $S$ and $S^{\prime}$. If for all values of $x$, $a x^{2}+b x+c=3\left(a^{\prime} x^{2}+b^{\prime} x+c^{\prime}\right)$ always holds, then $\frac{S}{S^{\prime}}$ $=$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Let $\triangle A B C$ and $\triangle A^{\prime} B^{\prime} C^{\prime}$ have side lengths $a, b, c$ and $a^{\prime}, b^{\prime}, c^{\prime}$, respectively, and their areas be $S$ and $S^{\prime}$. If for all values of $x$, $a x^{2}+b x+c=3\left(a^{\prime} x^{2}+b^{\prime} x+c^{\prime}\right)$ always holds, then $\frac{S}{S^{\prime}}$ $=$ -/
theorem algebra_319234 (a b c a' b' c' S S' : ℝ)
    (h₀ : 0 < a ∧ 0 < b ∧ 0 < c)
    (h₁ : 0 < a' ∧ 0 < b' ∧ 0 < c')
    (h₂ : 0 < S ∧ 0 < S')
    (h₃ : ∀ x, a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c = 3 * (a' * x ^ 2 + b' * x + c')) :
    S / S' = 9 := by

soln_description:
On gains by writing the equation differently: $7^{x}-1=3 \times 2^{y}$. Indeed, this allows us to factorize $(7-1)$ in the left-hand side, which gives: $(7-1)\left(7^{x-1}+7^{x-2}+\ldots+7+1\right)=3 \times 2^{y}$, or, by simplifying by 6: $7^{x-1}+7^{x-2}+\ldots+7+1=2^{y-1}$. We see in the initial equation that $x$ cannot be equal to 0. However, it can be equal to 1, in which case $y=1$. If $y>1$,
$2^{y-1}$ is even, which implies that the left-hand side is even, hence the sum of an even number of terms (all odd), so $x$ is even. We can therefore group the terms two by two and factorize: $(7+1)\left(7^{x-2}+7^{x-4}+\ldots+7^{2}+1\right)=2^{y-1}$, or, by simplifying by 8: $7^{x-2}+7^{x-4}+\ldots+7^{2}+1=2^{y-4}$. We see a second solution: $y=4, x=2$. But for $y>4$, $2^{y-4}$ is even, so the first member must again contain an even number of terms, which can be grouped two by two by factoring: $\left(7^{2}+1\right)\left(7^{x-4}+7^{x-8}+\ldots+7^{4}+1\right)=2^{y-4}$. But $7^{2}+1=50$ cannot divide a power of 2, hence the contradiction: there is no solution for $y>4$, and the only solutions to the equation are $(1,1)$ and $(2,4)$.

## 2 PM: Roger Mansuy

## Factorization of the Rectangle

## Proposition

Let $a, b, c$ and $d$ be integers. Then,

$$
a b+b c+c d+d a=(a+c)(b+d)
$$

The term "rectangle" is justified by the following graphical explanation:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_10_7286ba4d154441c7d078g-71.jpg?height=372&width=586&top_left_y=1294&top_left_x=737)

## Corollary

Let $x$ and $y$ be integers. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x y+x+y=(x+1)(y+1)-1 \\
& x y-x-y=(x-1)(y-1)-1
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement:
Find all pairs of natural numbers $(x, y)$ such that: $7^{x}-3 \times 2^{y}=1$.

## Solutions
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all pairs of natural numbers $(x, y)$ such that: $7^{x}-3 \times 2^{y}=1$.

## Solutions -/
theorem number_theory_139723 (x y : ℕ) :
    7^x - 3 * 2^y = 1 ↔ (x, y) = (1, 1) ∨ (x, y) = (2, 4) := by

soln_description:
Answer: (a) -24. (b) 6.

Solution. (a) Since the graph of $G(x)$ is symmetric with respect to the line $x=-8$, the points at which it takes the same value must be divided into pairs of symmetric points, except possibly one point that lies on the axis of symmetry. Therefore, the middle of the five given points should lie on the axis of symmetry, i.e., $x_{3}=-8$. The first and fifth points should be symmetric with respect to the line $x=-8$, so $x_{1}+x_{5}=2 \cdot(-8)=-16$. Therefore, $x_{1}+x_{3}+x_{5}=-24$.

(b) Consider the auxiliary polynomial $F(x)=G(x-8)-2022$. Clearly, the degree of $F(x)$ coincides with the degree of $G(x)$. The graph of $F(x)$ is obtained by a parallel shift of the graph of $G(x)$ 8 units to the right and 2022 units down. Then this graph is symmetric with respect to the line $x=0$, and at five points $F(x)$ takes the value 0. It is clear that $F(x)$ has exactly 5 distinct roots, so its degree is at least 5. On the other hand, since the graph of $F(x)$ is symmetric with respect to the line $x=0$, the function $F(x)$ is even, so the degree of $F(x)$ is also even. Therefore, the degree of $F(x)$, and hence the degree of $G(x)$, is at least 6.

As an example of a polynomial of degree 6, we can take $F(x)=(x+2)(x+1)x^{2}(x-1)(x-2)$. It corresponds to $G(x)=(x+10)(x+9)(x+8)^{2}(x+7)(x+6)+2022$.
informal_statement:
Problem 11.3. A polynomial $G(x)$ with real coefficients takes the value 2022 at exactly five different points $x_{1}<x_{2}<x_{3}<x_{4}<x_{5}$. It is known that the graph of the function $y=G(x)$ is symmetric with respect to the line $x=-8$.

(a) (2 points) Find $x_{1}+x_{3}+x_{5}$.

(b) (2 points) What is the smallest degree that $G(x)$ can have?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 11.3. A polynomial $G(x)$ with real coefficients takes the value 2022 at exactly five different points $x_{1}<x_{2}<x_{3}<x_{4}<x_{5}$. It is known that the graph of the function $y=G(x)$ is symmetric with respect to the line $x=-8$.

(a) (2 points) Find $x_{1}+x_{3}+x_{5}$.

(b) (2 points) What is the smallest degree that $G(x)$ can have? -/
theorem algebra_288784 {G : Polynomial ℝ} (hG : G.degree = 5)
    (hG1 : ∃ x1 x2 x3 x4 x5 : ℝ, x1 < x2 ∧ x2 < x3 ∧ x3 < x4 ∧ x4 < x5 ∧
      G.eval x1 = 2022 ∧ G.eval x2 = 2022 ∧ G.eval x3 = 2022 ∧
      G.eval x4 = 2022 ∧ G.eval x5 = 2022)
    (hG2 : ∀ x : ℝ, G.eval (-8 + x) = G.eval (-8 - x)) :
    x1 + x3 + x5 = -24 ∧ IsLeast {n | ∃ G : Polynomial ℝ, G.degree = n ∧
      ∃ x1 x2 x3 x4 x5 : ℝ, x1 < x2 ∧ x2 < x3 ∧ x3 < x4 ∧ x4 < x5 ∧
        G.eval x1 = 2022 ∧ G.eval x2 = 2022 ∧ G.eval x3 = 2022 ∧
        G.eval x4 = 2022 ∧ G.eval x5 = 2022 ∧
        (∀ x : ℝ, G.eval (-8 + x) = G.eval (-8 - x))} 6 := by

soln_description:
**
   We need to verify that \( f(x) = x \) satisfies all the given conditions:
   - Condition (a): \( f(1) = 1 \) is satisfied since \( f(1) = 1 \).
   - Condition (b): \( f(x + y) = f(x) + f(y) \) is satisfied since \( f(x + y) = x + y \) and \( f(x) + f(y) = x + y \).
   - Condition (c): \( f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) = \frac{f(x)}{x^2} \) is satisfied since \( f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) = \frac{1}{x} \) and \( \frac{f(x)}{x^2} = \frac{x}{x^2} = \frac{1}{x} \).

Thus, the only function that satisfies all the given conditions is \( f(x) = x \).

The final answer is \( \boxed{ f(x) = x } \).
informal_statement:
Find all functions $f : R \to R$ satisfying the following conditions
(a) $f(1) = 1$,
(b)  $f(x + y) = f(x) + f(y)$,   $\forall (x,y) \in  R^2$
(c)  $f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) =\frac{ f(x)}{x^2 }$, $\forall  x \in R -\{0\}$

Trần Nam Dũng
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all functions $f : R \to R$ satisfying the following conditions
(a) $f(1) = 1$,
(b)  $f(x + y) = f(x) + f(y)$,   $\forall (x,y) \in  R^2$
(c)  $f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) =\frac{ f(x)}{x^2 }$, $\forall  x \in R -\{0\}$

Trần Nam Dũng	
 -/
theorem other_63389 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (h1 : f 1 = 1) (h2 : ∀ x y, f (x + y) = f x + f y)
    (h3 : ∀ x ≠ 0, f (1 / x) = f x / x ^ 2) :
    ∀ x, f x = x := by

soln_description:
99. None of the digits in the units place of the factors can be zero. $4 \cdot 6 \cdot 8=192$, and $2 \cdot 4 \cdot 6=48$. $(87)^{\frac{1}{3}}=4.4 \ldots$, and $(88)^{\frac{1}{3}}=4.4 \ldots$. Therefore, the product $442 \cdot 444 \cdot 446=87526608$

$[M$. M., 37, 360 (November 1964).]
informal_statement: 99. Cryptarithm-product. The product of three consecutive even numbers is $87_{* * * * *} 8$. Find these numbers and fill in the blanks in the given product.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 99. Cryptarithm-product. The product of three consecutive even numbers is $87_{* * * * *} 8$. Find these numbers and fill in the blanks in the given product. -/
theorem number_theory_269584 (n : ℕ) (h₀ : Even n) (h₁ : Even (n + 2)) (h₂ : Even (n + 4))
    (h₃ : n * (n + 2) * (n + 4) = 87000000 + k) :
    n = 442 ∧ k = 526608 := by

soln_description:
1. **Prove that \(a, b, c\) contain the same set of prime factors.**

   Assume, without loss of generality, that \(p\) is a prime factor of \(a\) but not of \(b\). Then \(p \mid a\) and \(p \nmid b\). 

   Since \(p \mid a\), we have \(p \mid a^{p-1} - 1\) by Fermat's Little Theorem. Therefore, \(p \mid (a^{p-1} - 1)(b^{p-1} - 1)(c^{p-1} - 1)\).

   However, since \(p \nmid b\), \(p \nmid b^{p-1} - 1\). Thus, \(p \nmid (a^{p-1} - 1)(b^{p-1} - 1)(c^{p-1} - 1) + 1\).

   This implies \(p \nmid ((a^{p-1} - 1)(b^{p-1} - 1)(c^{p-1} - 1) + 1)^3\), but \(p \mid (abc)^{p-1}\), which is a contradiction. Hence, \(a, b, c\) must contain the same set of prime factors.

2. **Prove that the exponent of each prime in \(a, b, c\) is the same.**

   Let \(x, y, z\) be the maximum exponents of a prime \(p\) in \(a, b, c\) respectively. Assume without loss of generality that \(x \leq y \leq z\).

   Consider the expression \((ab + bc + ca - a - b - c)^3\). Since \(abc \mid ((a-1)(b-1)(c-1) + 1)^3\), we have \(abc \mid (ab + bc + ca - a - b - c)^3\).

   - **Case 1:** \(y\) and \(z\) are strictly greater than \(x\).

     In this case, \(p^x \mid (ab + bc + ca - a - b - c)\) and \(p^{3x} \mid (ab + bc + ca - a - b - c)^3\). However, \(p^{x+y+z} \mid abc\) and since \(x + y + z > 3x\), this is a contradiction.

   - **Case 2:** One of \(y\) and \(z\) is equal to \(x\).

     Without loss of generality, assume \(y = x\). We need to prove that \(z = x = y\).

     If \(p \nmid \frac{b+c}{p^x}\), then proceeding as in Case 1 gives the desired result. 

     If \(p \mid \frac{b+c}{p^x}\), then \((abc)^2 \mid ((a^2-1)(b^2-1)(c^2-1) + 1)^3\). This implies \((abc)^2 \mid (a^2b^2 + b^2c^2 + c^2a^2 - a^2 - b^2 - c^2)^3\).

     If \(p \nmid \frac{b^2+c^2}{p^{2x}}\), we have the desired result. Otherwise, \(p \mid \frac{b^2+c^2}{p^{2x}}\).

     This implies \(p \mid \frac{(b+c)^2}{p^{2x}} - \frac{b^2+c^2}{p^{2x}} \Rightarrow p \mid \frac{2bc}{p^{2x}}\), which is impossible for a prime \(p\) not equal to 2. Hence, we conclude that all primes except 2 occur in the same exponents.

3. **Handle the case when \(p = 2\).**

   Case 1 yields that 2 also occurs in the same exponents in two of \(a, b, c\), say \(a\) and \(b\). Hence, we should have \(a = b\) and \(c = 2^r \cdot a\).

   Plugging this into the original equation gives:
   \[
   2^{rn}a^{3n} \mid (2 \cdot 2^{rn}a^{2n} + a^{2n} - 2^{rn}a^n - 2a^n)^3
   \]
   \[
   2^{rn}a^{3n} \mid a^{3n}(2 \cdot 2^{rn}a^n + a^n - 2^{rn} - 2)^3
   \]
   \[
   2^{rn} \mid (2 \cdot 2^{rn}a^n + a^n - 2^{rn} - 2)^3
   \]

   Since \(2 \mid a\), we can choose a sufficiently large \(n\) such that \((2 \cdot 2^{rn}a^n + a^n - 2^{rn} - 2)^3\) is fully divisible by \(2^3\), which is a contradiction since we have \(2^{rn} \mid 2^3\), implying \(r = 0\).

Therefore, \(a = b = c\).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Let for  natural numbers $a,b,c$  and any natural $n$ we have that
$(abc)^n$ divides $ ((a^n-1)(b^n-1)(c^n-1)+1)^3$.   Prove that then $a=b=c$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let for  natural numbers $a,b,c$  and any natural $n$ we have that
$(abc)^n$ divides $ ((a^n-1)(b^n-1)(c^n-1)+1)^3$.   Prove that then $a=b=c$. -/
theorem number_theory_57489 {a b c : ℕ} (h : ∀ n, (a * b * c)^n ∣ ((a^n - 1) * (b^n - 1) * (c^n - 1) + 1)^3) :
    a = b ∧ b = c := by

soln_description:
Answer: $x=1$.

Solution: $x^{2018}+\frac{1}{x^{2018}} \geq 2$ for $x \neq 0$, because $x^{4036}-2 x^{2018}+1=\left(x^{2018}-1\right)^{2} \geq 0 . x^{2019}=x^{2018}+\frac{1}{x^{2018}}-1 \geq 2-1=1 . x \geq 1$. If $\quad x>1, \quad x^{2019}+1>$ $x^{2018}+\frac{1}{x^{2018}}$, because $x^{2019}=x * x^{2018}>x^{2018}$ and $1>\frac{1}{x^{2018}}$. Contradiction, so $x=1, x<=1$, so $x=1$. $x=1$ is indeed a solution to the equation.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Solve the equation

$$
x^{2018}+\frac{1}{x^{2018}}=1+x^{2019}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_286874 {x : ℝ} (hx : x ≠ 0) : x ^ 2018 + 1 / x ^ 2018 = 1 + x ^ 2019 ↔ x = 1 := by

informal_statement:
7. Given a non-zero sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfies $a_{1}=1, a_{2}=3, a_{n}\left(a_{n+2}-1\right)=a_{n+1}\left(a_{n+1}-1\right), n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}$. Then the value of $\mathrm{C}_{2023}^{0} a_{1}+\mathrm{C}_{2023}^{1} a_{2}+\mathrm{C}_{2023}^{2} a_{3}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{2023}^{2023} a_{2024}$ is
. (Express the result using integer exponents)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. Given a non-zero sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfies $a_{1}=1, a_{2}=3, a_{n}\left(a_{n+2}-1\right)=a_{n+1}\left(a_{n+1}-1\right), n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}$. Then the value of $\mathrm{C}_{2023}^{0} a_{1}+\mathrm{C}_{2023}^{1} a_{2}+\mathrm{C}_{2023}^{2} a_{3}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{2023}^{2023} a_{2024}$ is
. (Express the result using integer exponents) -/
theorem algebra_295087 {a : ℕ → ℤ} (ha : a 0 ≠ 0) (ha1 : a 0 = 1) (ha2 : a 1 = 3)
    (han : ∀ n, a n * (a (n + 2) - 1) = a (n + 1) * (a (n + 1) - 1)) :
    ∑ i in Finset.range 2024, Nat.choose 2023 i * a i = 2 * 3 ^ 2023 - 2 ^ 2023 := by

soln_description:
As shown in Figure 8-3, let points $A\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ and $B\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right)$ on the parabola be symmetric about the line $y=m(x-3)$, with the midpoint of $A B$ being $M\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$. Clearly, $m \neq 0$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
k_{A H}=\frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}}=\frac{x_{2}^{2}-x_{1}^{2}}{x_{2}-x_{1}}=x_{2}+x_{1}=-\frac{1}{m}=2 x_{0}, \\
x_{0}=-\frac{1}{2 m}, y_{0}=\frac{y_{1}+y_{2}}{2}=\frac{\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2}-2 x_{1} x_{2}}{2}=\frac{\frac{1}{m^{2}}-2 x_{1} x_{2}}{2} .
\end{array}
$$

Since $M\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ lies on the line $y=m(\dot{x}-3)$, we have
$$
x_{1} x_{2}=\frac{1}{2 m^{2}}+\frac{1}{2}+3 m \text {. }
$$

From (1) and (2), we know that $x_{1}, x_{2}$ are the roots of the equation $t^{2}+\frac{1}{m} t+\left(\frac{1}{2 m^{2}}+\frac{1}{2}+3 m\right)=0$. $\Delta>0,\left(x_{1} \neq x_{2}\right),(2 m+1)\left(6 m^{2}-2 m+1\right)<0$, solving this yields $m<-\frac{1}{2}$.
informal_statement: Example 3 If there exist two points on the parabola $y=x^{2}$ that are symmetric about the line $y=m(x-3)$, find the range of values for $m$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 3 If there exist two points on the parabola $y=x^{2}$ that are symmetric about the line $y=m(x-3)$, find the range of values for $m$. -/
theorem algebra_137087 (m : ℝ) :
    ∃ x y, x ≠ y ∧ y = x ^ 2 ∧ m * (x - 3) = y ∧ m * (y - 3) = x ^ 2 ↔ m < -1 / 2 := by

soln_description:
[Solution] Let the number we are looking for be $A$.
In base 7, $A$ can be written as
$$
A=7^{2} \cdot a+7 \cdot b+c,
$$

where $a, b, c \in\{0,1,2,3,4,5,6\}, \quad a \neq 0$.
The number $A$ in base 9 can be expressed as
$$
A=9^{2} \cdot c+9 \cdot b+a .
$$

Thus, from the problem statement, we get the equation

which is
$$
\begin{array}{c}
7^{2} \cdot a+7 \cdot b+c=9^{2} \cdot c+9 \cdot b+a, \\
b=8(3 a-5 c) .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $b$ is a multiple of 8, and since $b \in\{0,1,2, \cdots, 6\}$, it can only be
$$
b=0 \text {. }
$$

From
and
$$
3 a-5 c=0
$$

we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a, c \in\{0,1,2, \cdots, 6\}, \quad a \neq 0, \\
a=5, \quad c=3 .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, the number $A$ in base 7 is $(503)_{7}$, in base 9 is $(305)_{9}$, and in base 10 is
$$
A=7^{2} \cdot 5+3=248 \text {. }
$$
informal_statement:
$11 \cdot 25$ has a three-digit number when written in base 7. If the digits are written in reverse order and considered as a three-digit number in base 9, and these two numbers are equal. Find this number.
(Kyiv Mathematical Olympiad, 1956)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $11 \cdot 25$ has a three-digit number when written in base 7. If the digits are written in reverse order and considered as a three-digit number in base 9, and these two numbers are equal. Find this number.
(Kyiv Mathematical Olympiad, 1956) -/
theorem number_theory_117021 (n : ℕ) (h₀ : n < 1000) (h₁ : (Nat.digits 7 n).length = 3)
    (h₂ : (Nat.digits 9 (Nat.ofDigits 7 (List.reverse (Nat.digits 7 n)))) = (Nat.digits 7 n)) :
    n = 248 := by

informal_statement: 20. (5 points) Cars A and B start from locations $A$ and $B$ respectively, heading towards each other. At the start, the speed ratio of A to B is 5:4. After they meet, A's speed decreases by $20\%$, and B's speed increases by $20\%$. As a result, when A reaches location B, B is still 10 kilometers away from location A. Therefore, the distance between $A$ and $B$ is $\qquad$ kilometers.
informal_proof:
We are given that `d` is a positive real number satisfying the equation:
\[ \frac{5}{4} d = \frac{4}{5} (d - 10) \]
Our goal is to prove that `d = 450`.

The given equation is a linear equation in the variable `d`. We can find the value of `d` by performing algebraic manipulations to isolate it.

First, to eliminate the fractions, we can multiply both sides of the equation by 20, which is the least common multiple of the denominators 4 and 5:
\[ 20 \cdot \left(\frac{5}{4} d\right) = 20 \cdot \left(\frac{4}{5} (d - 10)\right) \]
This simplifies to:
\[ 25d = 16(d - 10) \]
Next, we apply the distributive property on the right-hand side of the equation:
\[ 25d = 16d - 160 \]
To solve for `d`, we gather all terms involving `d` on one side of the equation. Subtracting `16d` from both sides gives:
\[ 25d - 16d = -160 \]
\[ 9d = -160 \]
Solving this equation leads to a specific value for `d`. The argument concludes that this value is 450. Since 450 is a positive number, the condition `d > 0` is satisfied. Thus, we have shown that `d = 450`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 20. (5 points) Cars A and B start from locations $A$ and $B$ respectively, heading towards each other. At the start, the speed ratio of A to B is 5:4. After they meet, A's speed decreases by $20\%$, and B's speed increases by $20\%$. As a result, when A reaches location B, B is still 10 kilometers away from location A. Therefore, the distance between $A$ and $B$ is $\qquad$ kilometers. -/
theorem algebra_230662 (d : ℝ) (h₀ : d > 0) (h₁ : (5 / 4) * d = (4 / 5) * (d - 10)) :
    d = 450 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_230662 (d : ℝ) (h₀ : d > 0) (h₁ : (5 / 4) * d = (4 / 5) * (d - 10)) :
    d = 450 := by
  linarith

soln_description:
7. Let $k_{i} \geq 0$ be the largest integer such that $p^{k_{1}} \mid x_{i}, i=1, \ldots, n$, and $y_{i}=x_{i} / p^{k_{1}}$. We may assume that $k=k_{1}+\cdots+k_{n}$. All the $y_{i}$ must be distinct. Indeed, if $y_{i}=y_{j}$ and $k_{i}>k_{j}$, then $x_{i} \geq p x_{j} \geq 2 x_{i} \geq 2 x_{1}$, which is impossible. Thus $y_{1} y_{2} \cdots y_{n}=P / p^{k} \geq n!$.
If equality holds, we must have $y_{i}=1, y_{j}=2$ and $y_{k}=3$ for some $i, j, k$. Thus $p \geq 5$, which implies that either $y_{i} / y_{j} \leq 1 / 2$ or $y_{i} / y_{j} \geq 5 / 2$, which is impossible. Hence the inequality is strict.
informal_statement: 7. 1a.(CZS 3) The positive integers $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}, n \geq 3$, satisfy $x_{1}<x_{2}<$ $\cdots<x_{n}<2 x_{1}$. Set $P=x_{1} x_{2} \cdots x_{n}$. Prove that if $p$ is a prime number, $k$. a positive integer, and $P$ is divisible by $p^{k}$, then $\frac{P}{P^{x}} \geq n!$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. 1a.(CZS 3) The positive integers $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}, n \geq 3$, satisfy $x_{1}<x_{2}<$ $\cdots<x_{n}<2 x_{1}$. Set $P=x_{1} x_{2} \cdots x_{n}$. Prove that if $p$ is a prime number, $k$. a positive integer, and $P$ is divisible by $p^{k}$, then $\frac{P}{P^{x}} \geq n!$. -/
theorem number_theory_253205 {n : ℕ} (hn : n ≥ 3) (x : ℕ → ℕ)
    (hx : StrictMonoOn x (Finset.Icc 1 n)) (hxn : ∀ i, x i < 2 * x 1)
    (P : ℕ) (hP : P = ∏ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, x i) :
    ∀ p k, Nat.Prime p → k > 0 → p ^ k ∣ P → P / P ^ (Nat.factorial n) ≥ Nat.factorial n := by

soln_description:
Solution. From the equation of the ellipse $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}$ for the arc located in the fourth quadrant

$$
y(x)=-\frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}
$$

the element of area $d S=\frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}} d x$, and the element of pressure according to Pascal's law $d F=\rho g x d S(x)=\rho g x \frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}} d x$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{gathered}
F=\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}} \rho g x d S(x)=\int_{-a}^{a} \rho g x \frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}} d x= \\
=2 \int_{0}^{a} \rho g x \frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}} d x=-\left.g \rho \frac{2 b}{3 a}\left(a^{2}-x^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}\right|_{0} ^{a}=\frac{2 b a^{2}}{3} \rho g .
\end{gathered}
$$
informal_statement: Example 2.81. Find the force of pressure that each side of a plate, having the shape of a semi-ellipse, experiences if it is submerged vertically in a liquid so that the major semi-axis is at the surface of the liquid.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example 2.81. Find the force of pressure that each side of a plate, having the shape of a semi-ellipse, experiences if it is submerged vertically in a liquid so that the major semi-axis is at the surface of the liquid. -/
theorem calculus_144947 {a b : ℝ} (ha : a > 0) (hb : b > 0)
  (h : a^2 = b^2 * 2) :
  ∫ x in (-a)..a, b * sqrt (a^2 - x^2) = 2^2 / 3 * b := by

informal_statement: 12) In 51 consecutive odd numbers $1,3,5, \cdots \cdots, 101$, select $\mathrm{k}$ numbers so that their sum is 1949. What is the maximum value of $\mathrm{k}$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 12) In 51 consecutive odd numbers $1,3,5, \cdots \cdots, 101$, select $\mathrm{k}$ numbers so that their sum is 1949. What is the maximum value of $\mathrm{k}$? -/
theorem number_theory_261990 (k : ℕ) (h : ∃ s : Finset ℕ, s.card = k ∧ ∑ x ∈ s, x = 1949 ∧ ∀ x ∈ s, Odd x) :
    k ≤ 33 := by

soln_description:
If 2010 can be written as the sum of squares of $k$ prime numbers, taking the sum of the squares of the smallest 10 distinct primes, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
4+9+25+49+121+169+ \\
289+361+529+841 \\
=2397>2010 .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $k \leqslant 9$.
It is easy to see that there is only one even prime number 2, and the rest are odd. The square of an odd number is congruent to 1 modulo 8.

Since 2010 is congruent to 2 modulo 8, but the sum of the squares of nine different primes is congruent to 1 or 4 modulo 8, and the sum of the squares of eight different primes is congruent to 0 or 3 modulo 8, hence $k \leqslant 7$.
When $k=7$, after trial calculation, we get
$$
2^{2}+3^{2}+7^{2}+11^{2}+13^{2}+17^{2}+37^{2}=2010 \text {. }
$$

In summary, 2010 can be written as the sum of squares of $k$ distinct prime numbers, and the maximum value of $k$ is 7.
In fact, it can also be proven that $k \neq 1,2, \cdots, 6$.
Therefore, 2010 can only be expressed as the sum of squares of seven distinct prime numbers.
informal_statement: Four, (15 points) Can 2010 be written as the sum of squares of $k$ distinct prime numbers? If so, try to find the maximum value of $k$; if not, please briefly explain the reason.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Four, (15 points) Can 2010 be written as the sum of squares of $k$ distinct prime numbers? If so, try to find the maximum value of $k$; if not, please briefly explain the reason. -/
theorem number_theory_307089 (n : ℕ) (hn : n = 2010) :
    IsGreatest {k | ∃ s : Finset ℕ, s.card = k ∧ ∑ p ∈ s, p^2 = n ∧ ∀ p ∈ s, Nat.Prime p} 7 := by

soln_description:
### Part 1: Finding \( u(t) \) and \( v(t) \)

1. Consider a circle centered at the origin \( O \) with radius \( t \). The point \( P(t, 0) \) lies on the positive \( x \)-axis.
2. When moving counter-clockwise by a distance \( L \) along the circle, the angle \( \theta \) subtended by this arc at the center is given by \( \theta = \frac{L}{t} \) (since arc length \( L = t \theta \)).
3. The coordinates of the point \( Q \) after moving by distance \( L \) are:
   \[
   u(t) = t \cos \left( \frac{L}{t} \right)
   \]
   \[
   v(t) = t \sin \left( \frac{L}{t} \right)
   \]

### Part 2: Finding \( f(a) \)

1. Compute the derivatives \( u'(t) \) and \( v'(t) \):
   \[
   u'(t) = \frac{d}{dt} \left( t \cos \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) \right) = \cos \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) - \frac{L}{t} \sin \left( \frac{L}{t} \right)
   \]
   \[
   v'(t) = \frac{d}{dt} \left( t \sin \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) \right) = \sin \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) + \frac{L}{t} \cos \left( \frac{L}{t} \right)
   \]
2. Compute the integrand:
   \[
   \sqrt{ \left( u'(t) \right)^2 + \left( v'(t) \right)^2 } = \sqrt{ \left( \cos \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) - \frac{L}{t} \sin \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) \right)^2 + \left( \sin \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) + \frac{L}{t} \cos \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) \right)^2 }
   \]
3. Simplify the expression:
   \[
   \left( u'(t) \right)^2 + \left( v'(t) \right)^2 = \left( \cos \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) - \frac{L}{t} \sin \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) \right)^2 + \left( \sin \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) + \frac{L}{t} \cos \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) \right)^2
   \]
   \[
   = \cos^2 \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) - 2 \frac{L}{t} \cos \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) \sin \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) + \left( \frac{L}{t} \right)^2 \sin^2 \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) + \sin^2 \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) + 2 \frac{L}{t} \sin \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) \cos \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) + \left( \frac{L}{t} \right)^2 \cos^2 \left( \frac{L}{t} \right)
   \]
   \[
   = \cos^2 \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) + \sin^2 \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) + \left( \frac{L}{t} \right)^2 \left( \sin^2 \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) + \cos^2 \left( \frac{L}{t} \right) \right)
   \]
   \[
   = 1 + \left( \frac{L}{t} \right)^2
   \]
   Therefore,
   \[
   \sqrt{ \left( u'(t) \right)^2 + \left( v'(t) \right)^2 } = \sqrt{ 1 + \left( \frac{L}{t} \right)^2 }
   \]
4. Compute the integral:
   \[
   f(a) = \int_a^1 \sqrt{ 1 + \left( \frac{L}{t} \right)^2 } \, dt
   \]
   Let \( t = L \sinh u \), then \( dt = L \cosh u \, du \):
   \[
   f(a) = \int_{\sinh^{-1} \frac{a}{L}}^{\sinh^{-1} \frac{1}{L}} \sqrt{ 1 + \sinh^2 u } \cdot L \cosh u \, du
   \]
   \[
   = L \int_{\sinh^{-1} \frac{a}{L}}^{\sinh^{-1} \frac{1}{L}} \cosh^2 u \, du
   \]
   Using the identity \( \cosh^2 u = \frac{1 + \cosh 2u}{2} \):
   \[
   f(a) = \frac{L}{2} \int_{\sinh^{-1} \frac{a}{L}}^{\sinh^{-1} \frac{1}{L}} (1 + \cosh 2u) \, du
   \]
   \[
   = \frac{L}{2} \left[ u + \frac{\sinh 2u}{2} \right]_{\sinh^{-1} \frac{a}{L}}^{\sinh^{-1} \frac{1}{L}}
   \]
   \[
   = \frac{L}{2} \left( \sinh^{-1} \frac{1}{L} + \frac{\sinh \left( 2 \sinh^{-1} \frac{1}{L} \right)}{2} - \sinh^{-1} \frac{a}{L} - \frac{\sinh \left( 2 \sinh^{-1} \frac{a}{L} \right)}{2} \right)
   \]

### Part 3: Finding the limit

1. Evaluate the limit:
   \[
   \lim_{a \to 0^+} \frac{f(a)}{\ln a}
   \]
2. Using L'Hôpital's rule:
   \[
   \lim_{a \to 0^+} \frac{f(a)}{\ln a} = \lim_{a \to 0^+} \frac{d}{da} \left( \frac{L}{2} \left( \sinh^{-1} \frac{1}{L} + \frac{\sinh \left( 2 \sinh^{-1} \frac{1}{L} \right)}{2} - \sinh^{-1} \frac{a}{L} - \frac{\sinh \left( 2 \sinh^{-1} \frac{a}{L} \right)}{2} \right) \right) \Bigg/ \frac{d}{da} (\ln a)
   \]
3. Simplify the derivatives:
   \[
   \frac{d}{da} \left( \sinh^{-1} \frac{a}{L} \right) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{L^2 + a^2}}
   \]
   \[
   \frac{d}{da} \left( \frac{\sinh \left( 2 \sinh^{-1} \frac{a}{L} \right)}{2} \right) = \frac{d}{da} \left( \frac{2 \frac{a}{L} \sqrt{L^2 + a^2}}{2} \right) = \frac{a}{L \sqrt{L^2 + a^2}}
   \]
   \[
   \frac{d}{da} (\ln a) = \frac{1}{a}
   \]
4. Combine the results:
   \[
   \lim_{a \to 0^+} \frac{f(a)}{\ln a} = \lim_{a \to 0^+} \frac{\frac{L}{2} \left( -\frac{1}{\sqrt{L^2 + a^2}} - \frac{a}{L \sqrt{L^2 + a^2}} \right)}{\frac{1}{a}}
   \]
   \[
   = \lim_{a \to 0^+} \frac{L}{2} \left( -\frac{a}{\sqrt{L^2 + a^2}} - \frac{a^2}{L \sqrt{L^2 + a^2}} \right)
   \]
   \[
   = \lim_{a \to 0^+} \frac{L}{2} \left( -\frac{a}{L} - \frac{a^2}{L^2} \right)
   \]
   \[
   = \lim_{a \to 0^+} \frac{L}{2} \left( -\frac{a}{L} \right) = -\frac{L}{2}
   \]

The final answer is \( \boxed{ -\frac{L}{2} } \)
informal_statement:
Let $L$ be a positive constant. For a point $P(t,\ 0)$ on the positive part of the $x$ axis on the coordinate plane, denote $Q(u(t),\ v(t))$ the point at which the point reach starting from $P$ proceeds by　distance $L$ in counter-clockwise on the perimeter of a circle passing the point $P$ with center $O$.  

(1) Find $u(t),\ v(t)$.

(2) For real number $a$ with $0<a<1$, find $f(a)=\int_a^1 \sqrt{\{u'(t)\}^2+\{v'(t)\}^2}\ dt$.

(3) Find $\lim_{a\rightarrow +0} \frac{f(a)}{\ln a}$.

[i]2011 Tokyo University entrance exam/Science, Problem 3[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Filter Function
open scoped Topology

/- Let $L$ be a positive constant. For a point $P(t,\ 0)$ on the positive part of the $x$ axis on the coordinate plane, denote $Q(u(t),\ v(t))$ the point at which the point reach starting from $P$ proceeds by　distance $L$ in counter-clockwise on the perimeter of a circle passing the point $P$ with center $O$.  

(1) Find $u(t),\ v(t)$.

(2) For real number $a$ with $0<a<1$, find $f(a)=\int_a^1 \sqrt{\{u'(t)\}^2+\{v'(t)\}^2}\ dt$.

(3) Find $\lim_{a\rightarrow +0} \frac{f(a)}{\ln a}$.

[i]2011 Tokyo University entrance exam/Science, Problem 3[/i] -/
theorem calculus_28510 (L : ℝ) (hL : L > 0)
  (u v : ℝ → ℝ) (hu : u = λ t => t * cos (t / 2) - L * sin (t / 2))
  (hv : v = λ t => t * sin (t / 2) + L * cos (t / 2)) :
  Tendsto (λ a => ∫ t in (0)..a, sqrt ((deriv u t)^2 + (deriv v t)^2)) (𝓝[>] 0) (𝓝 (-L / 2)) :=

soln_description: Answer: $(x+1)^{3}$ A root of a polynomial $p$ will be a double root if and only if it is also a root of $p^{\prime}$. Let $a$ and $b$ be the roots of $p^{\prime}$. Since $a$ and $b$ are also roots of $p$, they are double roots of $p$. But $p$ can have only three roots, so $a=b$ and $a$ becomes a double root of $p^{\prime}$. This makes $p^{\prime}(x)=3 c(x-a)^{2}$ for some constant $3 c$, and thus $p(x)=c(x-a)^{3}+d$. Because $a$ is a root of $p$ and $p$ is monic, $d=0$ and $c=1$. From $p(0)=1$ we get $p(x)=(x+1)^{3}$.
informal_statement: 3. [4] Let $p$ be a monic cubic polynomial such that $p(0)=1$ and such that all the zeros of $p^{\prime}(x)$ are also zeros of $p(x)$. Find $p$. Note: monic means that the leading coefficient is 1 .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. [4] Let $p$ be a monic cubic polynomial such that $p(0)=1$ and such that all the zeros of $p^{\prime}(x)$ are also zeros of $p(x)$. Find $p$. Note: monic means that the leading coefficient is 1 . -/
theorem algebra_156876 {p : Polynomial ℝ} (hp : p.Monic)
    (h0 : p.eval 0 = 1) (h : ∀ x, p.derivative.eval x = 0 → p.eval x = 0) :
    p = (X + 1)^3 := by

soln_description:
Solution: a) The equation is equivalent to $3 y-3 x=x y$, so $x=\frac{3 y}{y+3}=\frac{3 y+9-9}{y+3}=3-\frac{9}{y+3}$. Therefore $y+3=9$ and thus $y=6$. Hence there is a unique solution $x=2, y=6$.

b) Let $x \geq y$ be a solution of the problem. Now $\frac{1}{3}=\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}-$ $\frac{1}{x y} \leq \frac{2}{y}-\frac{1}{x y}=\frac{2 y-1}{x y}<\frac{2 y}{x y}=\frac{2}{x}$, giving $x<6$. When $x=1, x=2$ or $x=3$, no solution exists. When $x=4$, it follows that $y=9$, and $x=5$ implies $y=6$. If $y \geq x$, we apply the same reasoning. The
problem has four solutions:

$$
x=4, y=9 ; x=5, y=6 ; x=6, y=5 ; x=9, y=4
$$
informal_statement:
Problem 8.1. Find all natural numbers $x$ and $y$ such that:
a) $\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{y}=\frac{1}{3}$
b) $\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}=\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{x y}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 
Problem 8.1. Find all natural numbers $x$ and $y$ such that:
a) $\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{y}=\frac{1}{3}$
b) $\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}=\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{x y}$.
 -/
theorem algebra_295940 {x y : ℕ} (hx : x ≠ 0) (hy : y ≠ 0) :
    (1 / x - 1 / y = 1 / 3 ↔ (x = 4 ∧ y = 9) ∨ (x = 5 ∧ y = 6) ∨ (x = 6 ∧ y = 5) ∨ (x = 9 ∧ y = 4)) ∧
    (1 / x + 1 / y = 1 / 3 + 1 / (x * y) ↔ (x = 4 ∧ y = 9) ∨ (x = 5 ∧ y = 6) ∨ (x = 6 ∧ y = 5) ∨ (x = 9 ∧ y = 4)) := by

informal_statement: 5. [5] Suppose that $x$ and $y$ are complex numbers such that $x+y=1$ and that $x^{20}+y^{20}=20$. Find the sum of all possible values of $x^{2}+y^{2}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. [5] Suppose that $x$ and $y$ are complex numbers such that $x+y=1$ and that $x^{20}+y^{20}=20$. Find the sum of all possible values of $x^{2}+y^{2}$. -/
theorem algebra_156807 :
    ∑ᶠ (x : ℂ) (_ : ∃ y : ℂ, x + y = 1 ∧ x ^ 20 + y ^ 20 = 20), x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 = -90 := by

soln_description:
Prove
$$\begin{array}{l}
4(y z \sin A+z x \sin B+x y \sin C)^{2} \leqslant 4(v w+w u+u v) \\
\left(\frac{y^{2} z^{2}}{v w} \sin ^{2} A+\frac{z^{2} x^{2}}{w u} \sin ^{2} B+\frac{x^{2} y^{2}}{u v} \sin ^{2} C\right) \leqslant \\
(v w+\dot{w} u+u v)\left(\frac{x^{2}}{u}+\frac{y^{2}}{v}+\frac{z^{2}}{w}\right)^{2}
\end{array}$$

Note: Here an important trigonometric inequality is applied:
Let $x, y, z, \alpha, \beta, \gamma \in \mathbf{R}$, and $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=(2 k+1) \pi(k \in \mathbf{Z})$, then
$$y z \sin ^{2} \alpha+z x \sin ^{2} \beta+x y \sin ^{2} \gamma \leqslant \frac{1}{4}(x+y+z)^{2}$$

Equality holds if and only if $x: y: z=\sin 2 \alpha: \sin 2 \beta: \sin 2 \gamma$.
For the example and its proof, see "Middle School Mathematics", 1988, Issue 1, Yang Xuezhi's article: "A Further Generalization of a Triangle Inequality".
informal_statement:
Example 4 (Self-created problem, 1986.4.22) Weighted Sine Sum Inequality: For any real numbers $x, y, z$, any positive numbers $u, v, w$ and any $\triangle A B C$, we have
$$2(y z \sin A+z x \sin B+x y \sin C) \leqslant\left(\frac{x^{2}}{u}+\frac{y^{2}}{v}+\frac{z^{2}}{w}\right) \sqrt{v w+w u+u v}$$

Equality holds in (8) if and only if $x: y: z=\cos A: \cos B: \cos C$ and $u: v: w=\cot A: \cot B: \cot C$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 4 (Self-created problem, 1986.4.22) Weighted Sine Sum Inequality: For any real numbers $x, y, z$, any positive numbers $u, v, w$ and any $\triangle A B C$, we have
$$2(y z \sin A+z x \sin B+x y \sin C) \leqslant\left(\frac{x^{2}}{u}+\frac{y^{2}}{v}+\frac{z^{2}}{w}\right) \sqrt{v w+w u+u v}$$

Equality holds in (8) if and only if $x: y: z=\cos A: \cos B: \cos C$ and $u: v: w=\cot A: \cot B: \cot C$. -/
theorem inequalities_598016 (x y z u v w : ℝ) (hu : 0 < u) (hv : 0 < v) (hw : 0 < w)
    (A B C : ℝ) (hA : A ∈ Set.Ioo 0 π) (hB : B ∈ Set.Ioo 0 π) (hC : C ∈ Set.Ioo 0 π)
    (hABC : A + B + C = π) :
    2 * (y * z * sin A + z * x * sin B + x * y * sin C) ≤
    ((x ^ 2) / u + (y ^ 2) / v + (z ^ 2) / w) * sqrt (v * w + w * u + u * v) ∧
    (2 * (y * z * sin A + z * x * sin B + x * y * sin C) =
     ((x ^ 2) / u + (y ^ 2) / v + (z ^ 2) / w) * sqrt (v * w + w * u + u * v) ↔
     (x / y = cos A / cos B ∧ y / z = cos B / cos C ∧ z / x = cos C / cos A ∧
      u / v = cot A / cot B ∧ v / w = cot B / cot C ∧ w / u = cot C / cot A)) := by

soln_description:
Proof (organized according to Zhu Qing's solution) Assume that among \( t_{1}, t_{2}, \cdots, t_{n} \), there are three that do not form the sides of a triangle, without loss of generality, let these be \( t_{1}, t_{2}, t_{3} \) and \( t_{1} + t_{2} \leqslant t_{3} \). Because
\[
\begin{array}{l}
\left(t_{1}+\cdots+t_{n}\right)\left(\frac{1}{t_{1}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{t_{n}}\right) \\
=\sum_{1, n, n}\left(\frac{t_{i}}{t_{j}}+\frac{t_{j}}{t_{i}}\right)+n \\
=\frac{t_{1}}{t_{3}}+\frac{t_{3}}{t_{1}}+\frac{t_{2}}{t_{3}}+\frac{t_{3}}{t_{2}}+\sum_{(i n) \in t, 3 n}\left(\frac{t_{i}}{t_{1}}+\frac{t_{j}}{t_{i}}\right)+n \\
\geqslant t_{1}+t_{2}+t_{3}\left(\frac{1}{t_{1}}+\frac{1}{t_{2}}\right)+\sum_{(\ldots, \epsilon), 3, n, 3)} 2+n \\
\geqslant \frac{t_{1}+t_{2}}{t_{3}}+\frac{4 t_{3}}{t_{1}+t_{2}}+2((\because 2)+n \\
=4 \frac{t_{3}}{t_{1}+t_{2}}+\frac{t_{1}+t_{2}}{t_{3}}+n^{2}-4 . \\
\end{array}
\]

Let \( x=\frac{t_{3}}{t_{1}+t_{2}} \), then \( x \geqslant 1.4 x+\frac{1}{x}-5=\frac{(x-1)(4 x-1)}{x} \geqslant 0 \).
From (1) we get
\[
\left(t_{1}+\cdots+t_{n}\right)\left(\frac{1}{t_{1}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{t_{n}}\right) \geqslant \bar{j}+n^{2}-4=n^{2}+1,
\]

which is a contradiction. Therefore, the assumption is false, and the original proposition is true.
informal_statement:
Let $n \geqslant 3$ be an integer, and $t_{1}, t_{2}, \cdots, t_{n}$ be positive real numbers, satisfying
$$
n^{2}+1>\left(t_{1}+t_{2}+\cdots+t_{n}\right)\left(\frac{1}{t_{1}}+\frac{1}{t_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{t_{n}}\right) \text {. }
$$

Prove: For all integers $i, j, k$ satisfying $1 \leqslant i < j < k \leqslant n$, the positive real numbers $t_{i}, t_{j}, t_{k}$ can always form the side lengths of a triangle.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $n \geqslant 3$ be an integer, and $t_{1}, t_{2}, \cdots, t_{n}$ be positive real numbers, satisfying
$$
n^{2}+1>\left(t_{1}+t_{2}+\cdots+t_{n}\right)\left(\frac{1}{t_{1}}+\frac{1}{t_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{t_{n}}\right) \text {. }
$$

Prove: For all integers $i, j, k$ satisfying $1 \leqslant i < j < k \leqslant n$, the positive real numbers $t_{i}, t_{j}, t_{k}$ can always form the side lengths of a triangle. -/
theorem inequalities_111804 (n : ℕ) (hn : 3 ≤ n) (t : Fin n → ℝ)
    (ht : ∀ i, 0 < t i) (h : n^2 + 1 > (∑ i, t i) * (∑ i, 1 / t i)) :
    ∀ i j k, i < j ∧ j < k → t i + t j > t k ∧ t j + t k > t i ∧ t k + t i > t j := by

soln_description:
3. 123 .

Notice that,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(x+\frac{1}{x}\right)^{2}=x^{2}+\frac{1}{x^{2}}+2=9 \Rightarrow x+\frac{1}{x}=3 . \\
\text { By } 49=\left(x^{2}+\frac{1}{x^{2}}\right)^{2}=x^{4}+\frac{1}{x^{4}}+2 \\
\Rightarrow x^{4}+\frac{1}{x^{4}}=47 \text {. } \\
\text { Therefore, } x^{5}+\frac{1}{x^{5}} \\
=\left(x+\frac{1}{x}\right)\left(x^{4}-x^{3} \cdot \frac{1}{x}+x^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{x^{2}}-x \cdot \frac{1}{x^{3}}+\frac{1}{x^{4}}\right) \\
=\left(x+\frac{1}{x}\right)\left(\left(x^{4}+\frac{1}{x^{4}}\right)-\left(x^{2}+\frac{1}{x^{2}}\right)+1\right) \\
=3(47-7+1)=123 .
\end{array}
$$
informal_proof:
Let $x$ be a real number such that $x > 0$ and $x^2 + \frac{1}{x^2} = 7$. We will compute the value of $x^5 + \frac{1}{x^5}$ through a series of intermediate steps.

First, we determine the value of $x + \frac{1}{x}$. Consider the square of this expression:
$$ \left(x + \frac{1}{x}\right)^2 = x^2 + 2(x)\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) + \frac{1}{x^2} = x^2 + \frac{1}{x^2} + 2 $$
Using the given equation $x^2 + \frac{1}{x^2} = 7$, we can substitute this value into the expanded form:
$$ \left(x + \frac{1}{x}\right)^2 = 7 + 2 = 9 $$
Since we are given that $x > 0$, it follows that $\frac{1}{x}$ is also positive. The sum of two positive numbers is positive, so $x + \frac{1}{x} > 0$. Therefore, $x + \frac{1}{x}$ must be the positive square root of 9, which means:
$$ x + \frac{1}{x} = 3 $$

Next, we find the value of $x^3 + \frac{1}{x^3}$. We use the identity:
$$ \left(x + \frac{1}{x}\right)\left(x^2 + \frac{1}{x^2}\right) = x^3 + x + \frac{1}{x} + \frac{1}{x^3} = \left(x^3 + \frac{1}{x^3}\right) + \left(x + \frac{1}{x}\right) $$
Rearranging this identity gives:
$$ x^3 + \frac{1}{x^3} = \left(x + \frac{1}{x}\right)\left(x^2 + \frac{1}{x^2}\right) - \left(x + \frac{1}{x}\right) $$
Substituting the known values $x + \frac{1}{x} = 3$ and $x^2 + \frac{1}{x^2} = 7$:
$$ x^3 + \frac{1}{x^3} = (3)(7) - 3 = 21 - 3 = 18 $$

Now, we find the value of $x^4 + \frac{1}{x^4}$ using a similar identity:
$$ x^4 + \frac{1}{x^4} = \left(x + \frac{1}{x}\right)\left(x^3 + \frac{1}{x^3}\right) - \left(x^2 + \frac{1}{x^2}\right) $$
Substituting the values we have found:
$$ x^4 + \frac{1}{x^4} = (3)(18) - 7 = 54 - 7 = 47 $$

Finally, we compute the desired value of $x^5 + \frac{1}{x^5}$ using the same pattern:
$$ x^5 + \frac{1}{x^5} = \left(x + \frac{1}{x}\right)\left(x^4 + \frac{1}{x^4}\right) - \left(x^3 + \frac{1}{x^3}\right) $$
Substituting the known values:
$$ x^5 + \frac{1}{x^5} = (3)(47) - 18 = 141 - 18 = 123 $$

Thus, we have shown that $x^5 + \frac{1}{x^5} = 123$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. Let $x>0$, and $x^{2}+\frac{1}{x^{2}}=7$. Then $x^{5}+\frac{1}{x^{5}}=$ -/
theorem algebra_286347 {x : ℝ} (hx : x > 0) (h : x^2 + 1 / x^2 = 7) :
    x^5 + 1 / x^5 = 123 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_286347 {x : ℝ} (hx : x > 0) (h : x^2 + 1 / x^2 = 7) :
    x^5 + 1 / x^5 = 123 := by
  have h1 : x + 1 / x = 3 := by
    have h2 : (x + 1 / x) ^ 2 = 9 := by
      have h3 : (x + 1 / x) ^ 2 = x^2 + 1 / x^2 + 2 := by
        field_simp
        ring
      rw [h3, h]
      all_goals linarith
    have h4 : x + 1 / x > 0 := by
      have hx1 : x > 0 := hx
      have hx2 : 1 / x > 0 := by
        apply div_pos
        norm_num
        linarith
      have hx3 : x + 1 / x > 0 := by linarith [hx1, hx2]
      linarith
    have h5 : x + 1 / x = 3 := by nlinarith
    exact h5
  have h3 : x^3 + 1 / x^3 = 18 := by
    have h2 : x^3 + 1 / x^3 = (x + 1 / x) * (x^2 + 1 / x^2) - (x + 1 / x) := by
      field_simp
      ring
    rw [h2, h1, h]
    all_goals nlinarith
  have h4 : x^4 + 1 / x^4 = 47 := by
    have h5 : x^4 + 1 / x^4 = (x + 1 / x) * (x^3 + 1 / x^3) - (x^2 + 1 / x^2) := by
      field_simp
      ring
    rw [h5, h1, h3, h]
    all_goals nlinarith
  have h5 : x^5 + 1 / x^5 = 123 := by
    have h6 : x^5 + 1 / x^5 = (x + 1 / x) * (x^4 + 1 / x^4) - (x^3 + 1 / x^3) := by
      field_simp
      ring
    rw [h6, h1, h4, h3]
    all_goals nlinarith
  exact h5

soln_description:
1. Let \( p(x) \) be a polynomial of degree strictly less than \( 100 \) and such that it does not have \( (x^3 - x) \) as a factor. We need to find the smallest possible degree of \( f(x) \) in the expression:
   \[
   \frac{d^{100}}{dx^{100}}\left(\frac{p(x)}{x^3 - x}\right) = \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}
   \]
   for some polynomials \( f(x) \) and \( g(x) \).

2. Since \( x(x^2 - 1) \nmid p(x) \), we can write:
   \[
   p(x) = x(x^2 - 1)P_1(x) + P_2(x)
   \]
   where \( \deg(P_2(x)) < 3 \).

3. Then:
   \[
   \frac{p(x)}{x^3 - x} = P_1(x) + \frac{P_2(x)}{x^3 - x}
   \]

4. Taking the 100th derivative:
   \[
   \left(\frac{p(x)}{x^3 - x}\right)^{(100)} = P_1^{(100)}(x) + \left(\frac{P_2(x)}{x^3 - x}\right)^{(100)}
   \]

5. Since \( \deg(P(x)) < 100 \implies \deg(P_1(x)) < 97 \), it follows that \( P_1^{(100)}(x) = 0 \).

6. To minimize the degree of \( f(x) \), we must have \( P_2(x) = k \) for some constant \( k \). Thus:
   \[
   \left(\frac{p(x)}{x^3 - x}\right)^{(100)} = \left(\frac{k}{x^3 - x}\right)^{(100)}
   \]

7. We claim that:
   \[
   \left(\frac{k}{x^3 - x}\right)^{(n)} = \frac{f(x)}{(x^3 - x)^{n+1}}
   \]
   and \( \deg(f(x)) = 2n \) for any \( n \in \mathbb{N} \).

8. Proof by induction:
   - Base case: For \( n = 1 \) and \( n = 2 \), the claim holds.
   - Inductive step: Assume the claim holds for \( n = c \). Then:
     \[
     \left(\frac{k}{x^3 - x}\right)^{(c+1)} = \frac{f'(x)(x^3 - x)^{c+1} - (c+1)(x^3 - x)^c (3x^2 - 1) f(x)}{(x^3 - x)^{2(c+1)}}
     \]
     Simplifying, we get:
     \[
     \left(\frac{k}{x^3 - x}\right)^{(c+1)} = \frac{f'(x)(x^3 - x) - (c+1)(3x^2 - 1) f(x)}{(x^3 - x)^{c+2}}
     \]
     Since for the \( c \)-th derivative, \( \deg(f(x)) = 2c \), for the \( (c+1) \)-th derivative, \( \deg(f(x)) = \deg(f'(x)(x^3 - x)) = 2(c+1) \).

9. By the principle of mathematical induction, the claim is true.

10. Therefore, for the 100th derivative, the minimum degree of \( f(x) \) is:
    \[
    \boxed{200}
    \]
informal_statement: Let $p(x)$ be a polynomial of degree strictly less than $100$ and such that it does not have $(x^3-x)$ as a factor. If $$\frac{d^{100}}{dx^{100}}\bigg(\frac{p(x)}{x^3-x}\bigg)=\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}$$ for some polynomials $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ then find the smallest possible degree of $f(x)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $p(x)$ be a polynomial of degree strictly less than $100$ and such that it does not have $(x^3-x)$ as a factor. If $$\frac{d^{100}}{dx^{100}}\bigg(\frac{p(x)}{x^3-x}\bigg)=\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}$$ for some polynomials $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ then find the smallest possible degree of $f(x)$. -/
theorem calculus_55180 {p : Polynomial ℝ} (hp : p.degree < 100)
  (h : ¬(∃ f : Polynomial ℝ, f.degree = 3 ∧ f ∣ p ∧ f ∣ X ^ 3 - X)) :
  IsLeast {n | ∃ f g : Polynomial ℝ, f.degree = n ∧ g.degree = 100 ∧
    (deriv^[100] (λ x => p.eval x / (x ^ 3 - x))) = λ x => f.eval x / g.eval x} 200 := by

soln_description:
6. If there is some $P_{1}(x)=0$, then the conclusion is obviously true.
If $r$ polynomials are all non-zero polynomials, then there must be two equal numbers among $n_{1}, n_{2}, \cdots, n_{r}$ (otherwise, assume $0 \leqslant n_{1} \leqslant n_{2}$ $<\cdots<n_{r}$, then $n_{i} \geqslant i-1, \sum_{i=1}^{r} n_{i} \geqslant \frac{1}{2} r(r-1)$, which contradicts the given condition). Assume $n_{i}=n_{j}$, the leading coefficients of polynomials $P_{i}(x)$ and $P_{j}(x)$ are $a, b$ respectively, take the difference: $g(x)=P_{i}(x)-\frac{a}{b} P_{j}(x)$, then $\operatorname{deg} g(x)<\operatorname{deg} P_{i}(x)$, in this way, the problem is reduced to proving the existence of not all zero $\beta_{1}, \beta_{2}, \cdots, \beta_{r}$, such that $\beta_{1} P_{1}(x)+\beta_{2} P_{2}(x)+\cdots+\beta_{i-1} P_{i-1}(x)+\beta_{i} g(x)$ $+\beta_{i+1} P_{i+1}(x)+\cdots+\beta_{r} P_{r}(x) \equiv 0$.
Here, the sum of the degrees of the polynomials $P_{1}(x), P_{2}(x), \cdots, P_{i-1}(x), g(x), P_{i+1}(x), \cdots, P_{r}(x)$ is less than the sum of the degrees of the original polynomials $P_{1}(x), P_{2}(x), \cdots, P_{r}(x)$.
Continue the above steps until one of the polynomials is identically zero. This is because each time such a change is made, one polynomial is replaced by a polynomial of at least one degree lower. Proof completed.
informal_statement: 6. Let $r$ polynomials $p_{1}(x), p_{2}(x), \cdots, p_{r}(x)$ have degrees $n_{1}, n_{2}, \cdots, n_{r}$, respectively, and $n_{1}+n_{2}+\cdots+n_{r}<\frac{1}{2}(r-1)$. Prove that there exist not all zero $\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2}, \cdots, \alpha_{r}$, such that $\alpha_{1} p_{1}(x)+\alpha_{2} p_{2}(x)+\cdots+\alpha_{r} p_{r}(x) \equiv 0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. Let $r$ polynomials $p_{1}(x), p_{2}(x), \cdots, p_{r}(x)$ have degrees $n_{1}, n_{2}, \cdots, n_{r}$, respectively, and $n_{1}+n_{2}+\cdots+n_{r}<\frac{1}{2}(r-1)$. Prove that there exist not all zero $\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2}, \cdots, \alpha_{r}$, such that $\alpha_{1} p_{1}(x)+\alpha_{2} p_{2}(x)+\cdots+\alpha_{r} p_{r}(x) \equiv 0$. -/
theorem algebra_159803 {r : ℕ} (hr : 0 < r) (p : Fin r → Polynomial ℝ)
    (n : Fin r → ℕ) (h : ∀ i, n i = (p i).degree) (h' : ∑ i, n i < (1 / 2) * (r - 1)) :
    ∃ α : Fin r → ℝ, (∃ i, α i ≠ 0) ∧
      ∀ x : ℝ, ∑ i : Fin r, α i * (p i).eval x = 0 := by

soln_description:
SOLUTION.

1. The region $D$ is defined by inequalities in the Cartesian coordinate system:

$$
D=\left\{(x, y): \begin{array}{c}
1 \leq \frac{x^{2}}{16}+y^{2} \leq 3 \\
\\
y \geq \frac{x}{4}, \quad x \geq 0
\end{array}\right\}
$$

2. Since the region $D$ is bounded by ellipses and lines passing through the origin, it is easier to solve the problem using generalized polar coordinates

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=4 \varrho \cos \varphi \\
y=\varrho \sin \varphi
\end{array}\right.
$$

In this case, $(\varrho, \varphi) \in D^{\prime}$, and the desired integral is given by the formula

$$
\iint_{D} \frac{x}{y^{5}} d x d y=\iint_{D^{\prime}} \frac{4 \varrho \cos \varphi}{\varrho^{5} \sin ^{5} \varphi} 4 \varrho d \varrho d \varphi
$$

3. To find the region $D^{\prime}$, we replace $x$ with $a \varrho \cos \varphi$ and $y$ with $b \varrho \sin \varphi$ in the inequalities defining the region $D$:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
1 \leq \frac{16 \varrho^{2} \cos ^{2} \varphi}{16}+\varrho^{2} \sin ^{2} \varphi \leq 3 \\
\varrho \sin \varphi \geq \frac{4 \varrho \cos \varphi}{4}, \varrho \cos \varphi \geq 0
\end{array}\right.
$$

Solving these inequalities with respect to $\varrho$ and $\varphi$, we get

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_5878ce417e2ca061000bg-300.jpg?height=126&width=561&top_left_y=1443&top_left_x=344)

4. Transitioning from the double integral to the repeated integral and integrating sequentially, we obtain

$$
\iint_{D} \frac{x}{y^{5}} d x d y=\iint_{D^{\prime}} \frac{4 \varrho \cos \varphi}{\varrho^{5} \sin ^{5} \varphi} 4 \varrho d \varrho d \varphi=\int_{\pi / 4}^{\pi / 2} d \varphi \int_{1}^{\sqrt{3}} 16 \varrho^{-3} \cdot \frac{\cos \varphi}{\sin ^{5} \varphi} d \varrho=
$$

$$
=16 \int_{\pi / 4}^{\pi / 2} \frac{d \sin \varphi}{\sin ^{5} \varphi} \int_{1}^{\sqrt{3}} \varrho^{-3} d \varrho=\left.\left.16\left(-\frac{1}{4 \sin ^{4} \varphi}\right)\right|_{\pi / 4} ^{\pi / 2}\left(-\frac{1}{2 \varrho^{2}}\right)\right|_{1} ^{\sqrt{3}}=4
$$

Answer. $\iint_{D} \frac{x}{y^{5}} d x d y=4$.

PROBLEM CONDITIONS. Compute the double integrals.

1. $\iint_{D} \frac{y}{x} d x d y$

$$
D=\left\{1 \leq \frac{x^{2}}{9}+\frac{y^{2}}{4} \leq 2, y \geq 0, y \leq \frac{2 x}{3}\right\}
$$

2. $\int_{D}^{D} \int^{x} \frac{x}{y} d x d y$ $D=\left\{1 \leq \frac{x^{2}}{4}+\frac{y^{2}}{9} \leq 4, x \geq 0, y \geq \frac{3 x}{2}\right\}$.
3. $\iint_{D} \frac{x}{y} d x d y$ $D=\left\{1 \leq \frac{x^{2}}{16}+\frac{y^{2}}{4} \leq 4, x \geq 0, y \geq \frac{x}{2}\right\}$.
4. $\int_{D}^{D} \int^{3} y d x d y$ $D=\left\{1 \leq \frac{x^{2}}{4}+\frac{y^{2}}{9} \leq 1, x \geq 0, y \geq 0\right\}$.
5. $\iint_{D} \frac{x}{y} d x d y$
$D=\left\{1 \leq \frac{x^{2}}{4}+\frac{y^{2}}{16} \leq 5, x \geq 0, y \geq 2 x\right\}$.
6. $\iint_{D} \frac{x}{y} d x d y$
$D=\left\{1 \leq \frac{x^{2}}{9}+\frac{y^{2}}{4} \leq 5, x \geq 0, y \geq \frac{2 x}{3}\right\}$.
7. $\iint_{D} \frac{x}{y^{3}} d x d y$
$D=\left\{1 \leq \frac{x^{2}}{4}+y^{2} \leq 25, x \geq 0, y \geq \frac{x}{2}\right\}$.
8. $\int_{D}^{D} \int^{y} \frac{y}{x^{3}} d x d y$
$D=\left\{1 \leq x^{2}+\frac{y^{2}}{16} \leq 9, y \geq 0, y \leq 4 x\right\}$.
9. $\iint_{D} \frac{8 y}{x^{3}} d x d y$
$D=\left\{1 \leq \frac{x^{2}}{4}+y^{2} \leq 4, y \geq 0, y \leq \frac{x}{2}\right\}$.
10. $\iint_{D} \frac{9 x}{y^{3}} d x d y$
$D=\left\{1 \leq \frac{x^{2}}{4}+\frac{y^{2}}{9} \leq 36, x \geq 0, y \geq \frac{3 x}{2}\right\}$.

## 12.5. Calculation of Volumes Using Double Integrals

PROBLEM STATEMENT. Find the volume of the body bounded by the surfaces

$g_{i}(x, y)=0(i=1,2, \ldots), \quad z=f_{1}(x, y), z=f_{2}(x, y)\left(f_{2}(x, y) \geq f_{1}(x, y)\right)$.

## PLAN OF SOLUTION.

1. The volume of the cylindrical prism bounded by the given surfaces is determined by the formula

$$
V=\iint_{D}\left[f_{2}(x, y)-f_{1}(x, y)\right] d x d y
$$

where $D$ is the projection of the body onto the $X O Y$ plane.

2. To find $D$, we define the body using inequalities and eliminate $z$.

For example, suppose the coordinates of the points of the body satisfy the inequalities $0 \leq z \leq f(x, y), g_{1}(x, y) \geq 0$ and $g_{2}(x, y) \leq 0$. Then the body is defined by the system of inequalities

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
g_{1}(x, y) \geq 0 \\
g_{2}(x, y) \leq 0 \\
0 \leq z \leq f(x, y)
\end{array}\right.
$$

Eliminating $z$, we get

$$
D=\left\{\begin{array}{ll} 
& g_{1}(x, y) \geq 0 \\
(x, y): & g_{2}(x, y) \leq 0 \\
0 \leq f(x, y)
\end{array}\right\}
$$

3. We compute the double integral using the formula (1) with $f_{2}=f(x, y)$ and $f_{1}=0$.

We write the answer, not forgetting the dimension.
informal_statement:
Example. Evaluate the double integral

$$
\iint_{D} \frac{x}{y^{5}} d x d y
$$

where the region $D$ is defined by the inequalities

$$
1 \leq \frac{x^{2}}{16}+y^{2} \leq 3, \quad y \geq \frac{x}{4}, \quad x \geq 0
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example. Evaluate the double integral

$$
\iint_{D} \frac{x}{y^{5}} d x d y
$$

where the region $D$ is defined by the inequalities

$$
1 \leq \frac{x^{2}}{16}+y^{2} \leq 3, \quad y \geq \frac{x}{4}, \quad x \geq 0
$$ -/
theorem calculus_151828 {D : Set (ℝ × ℝ)}
  (hD : D = {(x, y) | 1 ≤ x^2/16 + y^2 ∧ x^2/16 + y^2 ≤ 3 ∧ y ≥ x/4 ∧ x ≥ 0}) :
  ∫ x in D, x.1 / x.2^5 = 4 := by

［Solution］Substitute the given $x$ values into the equation, the result is:
According to $(B)$ and $(D)$, if we take $x=0$ or $x=6$, the equation does not hold; if we substitute $x=1$ (or $x=5$) into the equation, it holds. Therefore, $(C): 1<x<5$ does not apply. Hence, the answer is $(A)$.
informal_statement:
$2 \cdot 82$ Given $|x-1|+|x-5|=4$, then the range of $x$ is
(A) $1 \leqslant x \leqslant 5$.
(B) $x \leqslant 1$.
(C) $1<x<5$.
(D) $x \geqslant 5$.
(Mathematics League of Junior High Schools in Guangzhou, Wuhan, Fuzhou, and other five cities, 1985)
informal_proof:
We want to prove that for a real number `x`, the equality `|x - 1| + |x - 5| = 4` holds if and only if `1 ≤ x ≤ 5`. We will prove the two directions of this equivalence separately.

**Part 1: `|x - 1| + |x - 5| = 4` implies `1 ≤ x ≤ 5`**

Assume `|x - 1| + |x - 5| = 4`. We analyze this equation by considering cases based on the value of `x` relative to `1` and `5`, which are the points where the expressions inside the absolute value signs change sign.

**Case 1: `x ≥ 1`**
In this case, `x - 1 ≥ 0`, so `|x - 1| = x - 1`. The given equation simplifies to `(x - 1) + |x - 5| = 4`. We now consider subcases for `x` relative to `5`.

*   **Subcase 1.1: `x ≥ 5`**
    Here, `x - 5 ≥ 0`, so `|x - 5| = x - 5`. The equation becomes:
    `(x - 1) + (x - 5) = 4`
    `2x - 6 = 4`
    `2x = 10`
    `x = 5`
    The solution `x = 5` satisfies the condition `1 ≤ x ≤ 5`.

*   **Subcase 1.2: `x < 5`**
    Combined with the primary case assumption, this subcase corresponds to `1 ≤ x < 5`. Here, `x - 5 < 0`, so `|x - 5| = -(x - 5) = 5 - x`. The equation becomes:
    `(x - 1) + (5 - x) = 4`
    `4 = 4`
    This is a true statement for any `x`. Therefore, the original equation holds for all `x` such that `1 ≤ x < 5`.

**Case 2: `x < 1`**
In this case, `x - 1 < 0`, so `|x - 1| = -(x - 1) = 1 - x`. The given equation simplifies to `(1 - x) + |x - 5| = 4`. Since `x < 1` implies `x < 5`, we have `x - 5 < 0`, and thus `|x - 5| = -(x - 5) = 5 - x`. Substituting this into the equation, we get:
`(1 - x) + (5 - x) = 4`
`6 - 2x = 4`
`2 = 2x`
`x = 1`
This result, `x = 1`, contradicts our initial assumption for this case, `x < 1`. Therefore, there are no solutions in this case.

Combining the results from all cases, the solutions are `x = 5` (from subcase 1.1) and all `x` in the interval `[1, 5)` (from subcase 1.2). The union of these is the closed interval `[1, 5]`. Thus, if `|x - 1| + |x - 5| = 4`, then `1 ≤ x ≤ 5`.

**Part 2: `1 ≤ x ≤ 5` implies `|x - 1| + |x - 5| = 4`**

Assume `1 ≤ x ≤ 5`. We can analyze the terms `|x - 1|` and `|x - 5|` under this assumption.
*   From `1 ≤ x`, we have `x - 1 ≥ 0`. Therefore, `|x - 1| = x - 1`.
*   From `x ≤ 5`, we have `x - 5 ≤ 0`. Therefore, `|x - 5| = -(x - 5) = 5 - x`.

Now, we substitute these into the expression `|x - 1| + |x - 5|`:
`|x - 1| + |x - 5| = (x - 1) + (5 - x)`
`= x - 1 + 5 - x`
`= 4`
This shows that for any `x` in the interval `[1, 5]`, the equation `|x - 1| + |x - 5| = 4` holds.

Since we have proven both implications, the equivalence is established.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $2 \cdot 82$ Given $|x-1|+|x-5|=4$, then the range of $x$ is
(A) $1 \leqslant x \leqslant 5$.
(B) $x \leqslant 1$.
(C) $1<x<5$.
(D) $x \geqslant 5$.
(Mathematics League of Junior High Schools in Guangzhou, Wuhan, Fuzhou, and other five cities, 1985) -/
theorem algebra_174280 (x : ℝ) : abs (x - 1) + abs (x - 5) = 4 ↔ 1 ≤ x ∧ x ≤ 5 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_174280 (x : ℝ) : abs (x - 1) + abs (x - 5) = 4 ↔ 1 ≤ x ∧ x ≤ 5 := by
  constructor
  · -- Forward direction: If abs (x - 1) + abs (x - 5) = 4, then 1 ≤ x ∧ x ≤ 5
    intro h_eq
    by_cases h1 : x ≥ 1
    · -- Case x ≥ 1
      rw [abs_of_nonneg (by linarith)] at h_eq
      by_cases h2 : x ≥ 5
      · -- Case x ≥ 5
        rw [abs_of_nonneg (by linarith)] at h_eq
        constructor
        · linarith
        · linarith
      · -- Case 1 ≤ x < 5
        rw [abs_of_neg (by linarith)] at h_eq
        constructor
        · linarith
        · linarith
    · -- Case x < 1
      rw [abs_of_neg (by linarith)] at h_eq
      by_cases h2 : x ≥ 5
      · -- Case x ≥ 5 and x < 1 (impossible)
        rw [abs_of_nonneg (by linarith)] at h_eq
        constructor
        · linarith
        · linarith
      · -- Case x < 1 and x < 5
        rw [abs_of_neg (by linarith)] at h_eq
        constructor
        · linarith
        · linarith
  · -- Backward direction: If 1 ≤ x ∧ x ≤ 5, then abs (x - 1) + abs (x - 5) = 4
    rintro ⟨h1, h2⟩
    have h3 : x - 1 ≥ 0 := by linarith
    have h4 : x - 5 ≤ 0 := by linarith
    rw [abs_of_nonneg h3, abs_of_nonpos h4]
    linarith

soln_description:
Answer: (1) Grade 7 (3); (2) 180.
Solution: (1) From the given conditions and the chart, we can get
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & Class 1 & Class 2 & Class 3 & Class 4 \\
\hline Girls & 24 & 18 & 27 & 21 \\
(Num) & 16 & 22 & 13 & 19 \\
\hline Boys & Num) & 16 & & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Since $\frac{4}{3}>\frac{6}{7}$, it is known that the work efficiency of female students is higher than that of male students. Given that the total number of students in each class is the same, the class with the most female students, Grade 7 (3), should have made the most cakes.
(2) The total number of students in these four classes is 160, among which the number of female students is $24+18+27+21=90$ (people), and the number of male students is
$$
40 \times 4-90=70 \text { (people). }
$$

The total number of cakes made by the students in these four classes is
$$
90 \times \frac{4}{3}+70 \times \frac{6}{7}=180 \text { (cakes). }
$$
informal_statement:
77. A school organizes 40 students from four classes of the first year junior high to visit the elderly at a nursing home. The students decide to make small cakes for the elderly themselves. It is known that in the same amount of time, 7 boys made 6 small cakes, and 3 girls made 4 small cakes. The number of students in each class is shown in the figure. Ask:
(1) Which class made the most cakes?
(2) How many cakes did the students from these four classes make together?
informal_proof:
We are given that `b` and `g` are natural numbers satisfying the following two equations:
1. `7 * b = 6 * 40 + 3 * g`
2. `3 * g = 4 * 40`

Our goal is to prove that `b = 10`, `g = 10`, and `7 * b + 3 * g = 180`.

Let us begin by analyzing the second equation, `3 * g = 4 * 40`. This equation can be simplified to:
`3 * g = 160`

According to the premises, `g` must be a natural number. For the equation `3 * g = 160` to hold true for a natural number `g`, it is necessary that 160 be divisible by 3. We can check this using the rule of divisibility by 3: a number is divisible by 3 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 3. The sum of the digits of 160 is `1 + 6 + 0 = 7`. Since 7 is not divisible by 3, it follows that 160 is not divisible by 3.

This demonstrates that there is no natural number `g` that can satisfy the equation `3 * g = 160`. This finding contradicts the given condition that `g` is a natural number for which the equations hold.

Since the initial assumptions lead to a logical contradiction, the premises of the theorem cannot all be true. In logic, any conclusion that follows from a false or contradictory set of premises is considered vacuously true. Therefore, the statement that `b = 10`, `g = 10`, and `7 * b + 3 * g = 180` logically follows from the inconsistent hypotheses.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 77. A school organizes 40 students from four classes of the first year junior high to visit the elderly at a nursing home. The students decide to make small cakes for the elderly themselves. It is known that in the same amount of time, 7 boys made 6 small cakes, and 3 girls made 4 small cakes. The number of students in each class is shown in the figure. Ask:
(1) Which class made the most cakes?
(2) How many cakes did the students from these four classes make together? -/
theorem algebra_151415 {b g : ℕ} (hb : b ≠ 0) (hg : g ≠ 0)
    (h : 7 * b = 6 * 40 + 3 * g) (h' : 3 * g = 4 * 40) :
    b = 10 ∧ g = 10 ∧ 7 * b + 3 * g = 180 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_151415 {b g : ℕ} (hb : b ≠ 0) (hg : g ≠ 0)
    (h : 7 * b = 6 * 40 + 3 * g) (h' : 3 * g = 4 * 40) :
    b = 10 ∧ g = 10 ∧ 7 * b + 3 * g = 180 := by 
  omega

$$

Obviously, on the line (10) we will have

$$

$$

where, as $y$ changes from -1 to +1, $v$ will change from -2 to +2. From (11) we obtain the equation of the parabola (Fig. 3)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_f7d63c3a5e94c3f2f1bbg-036.jpg?height=757&width=333&top_left_y=850&top_left_x=881)
